any of the three 30,000 gallon propane storage tanks.  Bobtails are loaded from any of the three propane storage tanks for delivery to retail customers.  

Covered Processes Determination

Figure 1 is a layout view of the facility and shows the locations of the processing plant and storage tanks.  Both these processes are considered covered processes for purposes of this Process Safety Risk Management Plan (PSRMP).  The propane distribution operation is considered part of the covered process due to its location (co-location) adjacent to the processing plant storage tanks.  The co-location determination is based on the definition of process and the interpretations of what constitutes co-location as described in the Ohio EPA Risk Management Plan Co-Location Guidance of Non-Interconnected Regulated Substance Vessels, January 2002, and as described in Appendix A of the USEPA guidance document Risk Management Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities, March 2009.  Based on the close separation distances between all the storage tanks at the facility it was determined that the tanks are close enough together for a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of the total contents of one tank to cause the catastrophic failure of an adjacent tank.  


Off-Site Consequence Analysis:

The USEPA and Ohio EPA regulations require that TEC submit one "worst-case scenario," and one "alternate case scenario" for the listed flammable substances at their facility.  The listed flammable substances are as follows:

1.	Butane and Natural Gasolines (BG) - a mixture of natural gas liquids comprised of approximately:

¿	30% Butane
¿	10% Propane
¿	60% Pentane

2.	Propane  

US EPA defines the "worst-case scenario" as a release of the largest vessel containing the regulated substance.  For Butane, Propane and other flammable materials the released substance is assumed to explode and generate a pressure wave that can damage people and structures.  

An "alternate

case scenario" is defined to be a type of release of the regulated substance that is more likely or reasonable than the "worst case" but still results in an offsite impact.

DETERMINATION OF WORST-CASE SCENARIO - BG and Propane

Tank No.1 is the largest vessel or system containing BG and the worst-case scenario was determined to be the release of the entire contents of the tank into the air surrounding the tank.  The nominal water storage capacity of Tank 1 is 25,000 gallons or approximately 126,155 pounds of BG.  

Tank No.3 is the largest d vessel or system containing Propane and the worst-case scenario was determined to be the release of the entire contents of the tank into the air surrounding the tank.  The nominal water storage capacity of Tank 3 is 30,000 gallons or approximately 127,200 pounds of Propane.  

TEC follows the recommendations of the Certified Employee Training Program, National Propane Gas Association and only fills the BG and Propane tanks to 85% of their nominal capacity.  This is considered an Administrative Control under 40 CFR 68.25(b) Determining the Worst-Case Release Quantity.  The maximum pounds of BG and Propane that can be released were adjusted to 85% of the nominal capacity as follows:

¿	Tank No.1 BG - 107,232 pounds
¿	Tank No.3 Propane - 108,120 pounds.

Both the BG and Propane are liquefied under pressure and stored at ambient temperature.  

Estimated Release Rate and Distance to Toxic Endpoint

The US EPA program RMP*Comp Version 1.07 was used to calculate the estimated distance to endpoint and results in a conservative estimate of the potentially impacted area.  Assumptions used were selected in accordance with 40 CFR 68.25 where the estimated quantity released is the entire contents of the tank, considering administrative controls.  The release occurs over a ten minute period whereas a vapor cloud forms and explodes generating a pressure wave.  The distance to endpoint is that distance the pressure wave trav

els and dissipates until is reaches an overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi).  The distance to endpoint is estimated to be 0.4 miles for both Butane and Propane.  The RMP*Comp program results for Butane and Propane are as follows:

All supporting calculations for the worst-case scenario are incl

uded at end of this section.

Offsite Impacts:  Population and Environment

The off-site impacts from a worst-case release of either BG or Propane are identical and therefore will be discussed together in the analysis below.  

ArcView 9.3 was used to estimate the potential public receptors within the distance to the endpoint.  ArcView 9.3 provides databases from the Environmental Protection Agency, the Bureau of Census (2010 Tiger/Line Shapefiles), and other federal agencies.  These databases are presented in a geographic context on maps that contain jurisdictional entities (states, counties, cities and towns, zip codes, congressional districts and others), detailed network of roads, rivers, and railroads, schools, hospitals, churches, cemeteries, airports, and other landmark features.  The demographic information in ArcView 9.3 is based on the 2010 Census and the Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc. (ESRI) Community Data.

Census block group data are usually calculated in ArcView 9.3 using the proportional split method.  This method was utilized where there was a census block group located partially within the radius of the distance to endpoint and partially outside of the radius.  However, during the analysis population data were not available in the census block groups for the impacted area.  The rural nature of the surrounding area allowed a hand count of household units (houses) to be done using a Google Earth aerial photo.  The residential population within the impacted area was estimated by multiplying the total household units seen on the aerial photo by average household  for Muskingum County (2.58 persons per household).  All houses seen on the aerial were assumed to be occupied and field verification was not performed.  

The analyses indicate that the area within the impact radius is 0.5024 square miles.  A total of 7 housing units and a total population of 18 people are within the impact radius.  Table 3-2 summarizes the public rece

ptors that are affected by the worst case release scenario.

Figure 3-1 illustrates the radius of impact and the public receptors for both Butane and Propane worst-case release scenarios.  Except for two businesses and several houses, there are no other public receptors such as schools, hospitals or churches within the impact radius.

DETERMINATION OF ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO - BG and Propane

The alternative release scenario was selected using the USEPA document entitled Risk Management Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities (March, 2009).  The alternate scenario is defined to be a more likely scenario than the "worst case" that still produces an offsite impact.  The Pull-Away scenario was selected as the more likely scenario to occur.  In this scenario a bulk tanker truck pulls away from the loading rack with the hose still attached to the truck.  The hose ruptures and releases the contents of the hose and additional gas from the truck or tank systems until the mitigating measures take affect.  

Passive mitigation was included in the analysis and includes the following components:

1.	Smart Hose - The Smart Hose has a cable inside so that if the hose breaks the flapper valves at either end of the hose clo

ses.  Hose pressure is also monitored and if a drop is detected the flapper valves close.

2.	Snappy Joe - The Snappy Joe is a valve at the bulkhead that closes if there is a sudden pressure drop in the piping pressure due to the bulkhead being torn off.  The valve closes and prevents gas from escaping from the bulk storage tank piping.  

The US EPA program RMP*Comp Version 1.07 was used to calculate the estimated distance to endpoint and results in a conservative estimate of the potentially impacted area.  The release occurs over a time period of less than one minute due to the passive mitigation measures.  A vapor cloud forms and explodes generating a pressure wave.  

The flammable mixture BG was not able to be analyzed for the alternative release scenario using RMP*Comp.  According to the USEPA Risk Management Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis the analysis of flammable mixtures can be done using the major component of the mixture with the highest heat of combustion.  The heat of combustion values for butane, pentane and propane are 45,719, 44,697 and 46,333 kjoule/kg, respectively.  Of the three major components, propane has the highest heat of combustion as listed in Exhibit C-1 of the guidance.  Propane and butane together comprise 40% of the mixture and have similar values for heat of combustion.  Propane was selected as the chemical to be modeled using RMP*Comp.  

The distance to endpoint estimated for propane using the RMP*Comp model is 0.02 miles.  The RMP*Comp program results for propane are as follows:

Offsite Impacts:  Population and Environment

Due to the small distance to endpoint and the rural nature of the site the ArcView 9.3 results from the worst-case scenario were not applied to the alternative case scenario.  A visual analysis was done using a Google Earth aerial photo to identify any public receptors within the distance to endpoint.  Within the 0.02 mile (~106 feet) impact radius there are no residential populations and no housing units.  No schools, churches, hospitals or businesses are located within the distance to endpoint area.  Table 3-4 shows that no public receptors are affected by the alternate-case release scenario.  Figure 3-2 shows the radius of impact that extends approximately 25 feet beyond the east fence line of the facility.  No off-site public receptors are impacted under the alternative scenario.
